title: 109_s765
content: The Act may be cited as the "Math and Science Incentive Act of 2005". Congress finds that the United States needs a strong scientific and technical enterprise, which requires producing more scientists and engineers. The education system must encourage students to study science and mathematics and pursue related careers, as current performance in these fields lags behind international peers. The United States needs to recommit to leadership in science, mathematics, and engineering, especially in areas like nanotechnology. A program of loan forgiveness can attract students to careers in these fields, including teaching. Encouraging students to pursue careers in science, mathematics, engineering, and technology, including teaching, can help the United States maintain its technological leadership. Establishment of program. The Secretary will implement a program to cover interest payments on loans for eligible undergraduate students who have applied in accordance with the Act. The program covers interest payments on loans for eligible undergraduate students who obtained loans as undergraduates, are new borrowers, are teachers of STEM subjects, and enter into an agreement with the Secretary. The program covers interest payments on loans for eligible undergraduate students who obtained loans as undergraduates, are new borrowers, are teachers of STEM subjects, and enter into an agreement with the Secretary. Eligible individuals must complete 5 consecutive years of service in a specified position to qualify for the program. The Secretary will not make payments for interest that accrues before the repayment period begins on a loan. The program covers interest payments on loans for eligible undergraduate students who obtained loans as undergraduates, are new borrowers, are teachers of STEM subjects, and enter into an agreement with the Secretary. The Secretary will not make payments for interest that accrues before the repayment period begins on a loan. In selecting participants for the program, the Secretary shall choose among eligible applicants based on national security, homeland security, and economic security needs. The Secretary selects program participants based on national security, homeland security, and economic security needs, as well as the academic record or job performance of the applicant. The Secretary selects program participants based on national security, homeland security, and economic security needs, as well as the likelihood of the applicant to complete the 5-year service obligation, remain in science, mathematics, or engineering, and other relevant criteria determined by the Secretary. Loan interest payments under this Act are subject to the availability of appropriations. If funds are insufficient, priority will be given to individuals who received interest payments in the previous fiscal year. The Secretary has the authority to establish regulations. The Secretary can prescribe regulations for interest payments made on behalf of individuals. The period for interest payments begins on the agreement's effective date, continues after service completion, and ends upon loan repayment completion. The service obligation ends after completion of the repayment period, payment of $10,000 by the Secretary, borrower's failure to fulfill the obligation, or if the borrower's income exceeds 4 times the threshold for 6 months. The borrower's service obligation ends if their income exceeds 4 times the threshold for 6 months after the end of a calendar year. The Secretary will pay eligible lenders according to regulations. The Secretary will pay eligible lenders for the interest accrued on loans of selected student borrowers. Eligible individuals must submit a complete application for loan interest repayment as required by the Secretary. The individual must agree to repay the Secretary if they fail to complete the required 5 years of service. Consolidation loans under specific acts can also be eligible for loan interest repayment. The borrower must use the loan amount to repay specific types of loans under the Higher Education Act or Federal Direct Consolidation Loan. Borrowers cannot receive benefits under both this section and other programs for the same service. No borrower can receive benefits under both this section and other loan forgiveness programs for the same service. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education, and "mathematics, science, or engineering professional" is defined as someone with a degree in science, mathematics, or engineering working in a related field, including as a professor at a higher education institution. SEC. 5. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal year 2006 and the following 5 years is provided under this Act.
